instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1706: What is A1706? A1706 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3071, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00239, 820-00923..
definitions.820-00239: What is 820-00239? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.SMC_DELAYED_PWRGD: What is SMC_DELAYED_PWRGD? SMC_DELAYED_PWRGD is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a pre-requisite for SYS_PWROK_R and PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK..
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.PPVCCSA_S0_CPU: What is PPVCCSA_S0_CPU? Main power rail for the CPU. If this is missing the machine will act braindead. This is NOT shorted to ground if it has a low resistance â€“ this is a common mistake people make. A chip that requires high power at a low voltage like a CPU or GPU will have a low measured resistance to ground..
definitions.CPUVR_PGOOD: What is CPUVR_PGOOD? CPU_VR_PGOOD Is a signal present when CPU_VR_EN is presenT. CPU_VR_PGOOD is a prerequisite along with ALL_SYS_PWRGD to create PM_S0_PGOOD and PM_PCH_PWROK and PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK which are necessary for the machine to turn on and boot..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, Touchbar, <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A, No Chime
threads.message:
Hello folks,

I recently bought a water damaged <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> touch bar that doesn't have any chime (and obviously no display or fan). When connected to a USB-C monitor, the monitor turns on but no display (indicating its drawing [I]some[/I] power). Here are the measurements I took - do you have suggestions on where I should check next? There was a considerable amount of water residue / corrosion near the battery area.

CPU gets luke warm (not really hot) after leaving it for 5 minutes.

[U]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A[/U]
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - <CAPACITOR>C6483</CAPACITOR> - 12.89V
PP5VS4 - L7600 - 5.06v
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> - <RESISTOR>R7103</RESISTOR> - 3.19v
<SIGNAL>CPU_VCCST_PWRGD</SIGNAL>- probe point - 0.98v
<SIGNAL>PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK</SIGNAL> - probe point - 3.29v
<SIGNAL>SMC_DELAYED_PWRGD</SIGNAL> - <RESISTOR>R5191</RESISTOR> - 3.38v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_CPU</SIGNAL> - <CAPACITOR>C7903</CAPACITOR> - 12.03v
[B]<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> - 0V (resistance to ground 17 ohm, which I [I]assume [/I]is normal)[/B]
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_VCORE1</SIGNAL> - Pin 3 <CHIP>U7210</CHIP> - 5.07v

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> - probe point - 5.06v

I tried reading the schematic but am lost at how <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> is produced. I guess it could be <CHIP>U7210</CHIP>, but was hoping someone has seen something like this before.

Thank you! I really hope this isn't a dead CPU, as I was hoping to resurrect this as my personal laptop.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, Touchbar, <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A, No Chime
threads.message:
Any liquid sign around <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>, or <CHIP>U7210</CHIP>/20?
Do you get voltage at L7270?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, Touchbar, <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A, No Chime
threads.message:
Everything near <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>, <CHIP>U7210</CHIP>, and <CHIP>U7220</CHIP>  looks really clean.

<SIGNAL>CPUVR_SWSA</SIGNAL> - L7270 - 1.10v
<SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> - <RESISTOR>R7270</RESISTOR> - 1.03v
<SIGNAL>CPUVR_PGOOD</SIGNAL> - 3.02v

<SIGNAL>CPUCORE_PWM1</SIGNAL> (the PWM pin to <CHIP>U7210</CHIP>) - 2.48v (measured as DC)
[B]<SIGNAL>CPUCORE_FCCM</SIGNAL> - 14.1mV (600k to ground) - [/B]Another clue I am guessing contributing to why I'm not getting anything out of <CHIP>U7210</CHIP>. I'll continue looking near <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> I guess.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, Touchbar, <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A, No Chime
threads.message:
Very likely something affected by corrosion.
Disconnect anything from MLB and check if <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> appears.
